unnormalised: New Delhi: Provisional data from the 2023 census reveals significant demographic shifts across India. The population stands at approx. 1.42 billion, a 1.2% increase from the last census in 2021. The sex ratio shows improvement, with 930 females per 1000 males compared to 920 in '21.
normalised: New Delhi: Provisional data from the two thousand twenty three census reveals significant demographic shifts across India. The population stands at approximately one point four two billion, a one point two percent increase from the last census in two thousand twenty one. The sex ratio shows improvement, with nine hundred and thirty females per one thousand males compared to nine hundred and twenty in twenty one.

unnormalised: Urbanization continues to rise, with 36% of the population now residing in cities, up from 34% in '21. The National Capital Territory of Delhi recorded the highest population density at 11,320 people per sq km, whereas Arunachal Pradesh reported the lowest at 17 per sq km. Literacy rates have also seen a boost, reaching 80% overall, with female literacy increasing by 2%.
normalised: Urbanization continues to rise, with thirty six percent of the population now residing in cities, up from thirty four percent in twenty one. The National Capital Territory of Delhi recorded the highest population density at eleven thousand three hundred and twenty people per square kilometer, whereas Arunachal Pradesh reported the lowest at seventeen per square kilometer. Literacy rates have also seen a boost, reaching eighty percent overall, with female literacy increasing by two percent.

unnormalised: Concerns remain regarding regional disparities. States like Bihar and Uttar Pradesh continue to experience higher population growth rates compared to Southern states like Kerala and Tamil Nadu. The under-5 mortality rate also shows significant variation, ranging from 20 per 1000 live births in Kerala to 45 per 1000 in Bihar.
normalised: Concerns remain regarding regional disparities. States like Bihar and Uttar Pradesh continue to experience higher population growth rates compared to Southern states like Kerala and Tamil Nadu. The under five mortality rate also shows significant variation, ranging from twenty per one thousand live births in Kerala to forty five per one thousand in Bihar.

unnormalised: The complete census report, including detailed data on caste, religion, and socio-economic indicators, is expected to be released by the Registrar General of India by 31/12/2024. The government plans to use this data to formulate targeted policies aimed at addressing regional inequalities and improving the overall quality of life for all citizens.
normalised: The complete census report, including detailed data on caste, religion, and socio economic indicators, is expected to be released by the Registrar General of India by thirty first December two thousand twenty four. The government plans to use this data to formulate targeted policies aimed at addressing regional inequalities and improving the overall quality of life for all citizens.
